name: Swiss Steak
headline: Swiss Steak
description: For dinner tonight, try Alton Brown's Swiss Steak cutlets from Good Eats on Food Network, cooked in bacon drippings and smothered in an oniony beef gravy.
keywords: Dutch Oven,European Recipes,American,Steak,Celery,Bacon Recipes,Beef,Tomato,Onion Recipes,Swiss Cheese Recipes,Main Dish,Recipes for Parties,Sauteing Recipes
recipeIngredient: 2 pounds beef bottom round, trimmed of excess fat
1/4 cup vegetable oil or bacon drippings

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F.

Cut the meat with the grain into 1/2-inch thick slices and season on both sides with the salt and pepper. Place the flour into a pie pan. Dredge the pieces of meat on both sides in the flour mixture. Tenderize the meat using a needling device, until each slice is 1/4-inch thick. Dredge the slices on both sides once more and set aside.

Add enough of the bacon drippings or vegetable oil to just cover the bottom of a 4 to 5-quart Dutch oven set over medium-high heat. Once the oil begins to shimmer, add the steaks to the pan, being careful not to overcrowd. Cook until golden brown on both sides, approximately 2 minutes per side. Remove the steaks to a plate and repeat until all of the steaks have been browned.

Remove the last steaks from the pot and add the onions, garlic, and celery. Saute for 1 to 2 minutes. Add the tomato paste and stir to combine. Next add the tomatoes, paprika, oregano, Worcestershire sauce and beef broth and stir to combine. Return the meat to the pot, submerging it in the liquid. Cover the pot and place it in the oven on the middle rack. Cook for 1 1/2 to 2 hours or until the meat is tender and falling apart.

review.reviewBody: I love this recipe. But to make it easier, I use cube steak already tenderized saves 15 to 20 minutes of Prep time and just as wonderful.
I made this for supper tonight. It was a great hit with my family! My husband went back for three helpings! We had it with white rice but next time we might have mashed potatoes! üòã

Absolutely delicious.  I will be on the watch for inexpensive cuts of beef.  This recipe was very straightforward and we ended up with a delicious meal over our leftover Thanksgiving mashed potatoes.  Thank you!

This is a fantastic dish.  Our entire family loves it (including the kids!!). I often start it in a skillet and finish it in the slow cooker.  Occasionally, I substitute venison steak for the beef.  Delicious.
Very, very good!!!!
Made this last night.... Fantastic..  The flavor profile on this recipe is very good..  Lots of deep flavors and very tender meat..
This recipes got rave reviews from my impromptu dinner party. Mashed potatoes and corn on the cob rounded out the meal. Shared the recipe with my guestsüòÅ
Great recipe! Followed directions but did add some sliced colored peppers. Took it over the top. Will definitely make it again. Thank you Alton for another great recipe!
This was wonderful. I added mash and baby peas as my sides.

Delish!  When I make someone else's recipe I tend to tweak it, but this time I followed as is and glad I did!  I was unsure about about oregano and smoked paprika in Swiss Steak-definitely not the Swiss Steak of my childhood-but it was Really Good!  I guess I did tweak it a little bit, I used tapioca flour instead of regular flour for a low carb version.  I feel I keep making the same low carb meals all the time so this will be a great addition to the rotation!
The sauce is great. Very tasty and great consistency. Served over mashed parsnips.
I make this often. It is my favorite Swiss Steak recipe. Sometimes I put the meat in the crockpot and pour the sauce over and cook on low for 6-8 hours. Making it today in fact.

This is truly AMAZING!!! Only thing different I did was used tomato sauce instead of diced tomatoes because of my Grandson lol and used cube steaks. Trust me, they will be the most tender ones you‚Äôve EVER had; no knife needed! !  I used the crock pot instead of the oven for about 2-2 & a half hours. I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôll turn out the same though it was just my preference. SO delicious! You gotta try it!!!

I used ‚Äòcube steak‚Äô since it was on super sale and it worked well in this recipe.
The braising liquid was pretty thick at the end and was delicious over mashed potatoes, Everyone in my family liked this dish and requested to make it again.
When McCormick stopped making the Swiss steak packet mix, I tried several recipes to find the right one. Mr. Brown‚Äôs recipe is it. I rarely deviate from his instructions. Great leftovers, too.
This was absolutely delicious! Only change was I used green pepper instead of celery. Served over rice. Will definitely make this again!
I tried a different recipe for swiss steak, and it was terrible. I was almost going to give up on the dish, and then I found this recipe. I'm so glad I tried it
I meant to put 5 stars!  This is an oldie;  but goodie recipe done the right way!

Relatively easy, whole family loved it!!!
That rarely happens! Thanks
I thought about this a week or two ago and I thought I have not made this in so long so I looked on this app and lo and behold Alton never fails very good thanks Texdilla

I doubled the recipe and used very large Dutch oven. Used more tomato paste and I added 2 very large carrots cut in half then chopped. Was a big hit with all ages and the kids did not really notice the vegetables because the sauce was ‚Äúnummy‚Äù. Not really sure they even knew it was meat.       Rhon19
Delicious! Whole family loved it. I served it with thin spaghetti. Subbed Italian Seasoning for oregano.
I really want to give this one 5 stars! Made it with peppers, not celery. We loved it so much that we ate it 3 nights in a row and were loving it every time!
I have made this many times and it‚Äôs always delicious I do substitute green yellow or red bell peppers for the celery because I‚Äôm allergic to celery and my family and I love it

My go to Swiss steak recipe now for 5-7 years. There‚Äôs no need to tweak the recipe unless you are changing serving size. Tip- have your butcher run the steak through the tenderizer once. A big time saver.
Wonderful meal‚Ä¶we loved this and even my autistic granddaughter asked for seconds. Cut the steak with a fork, so tender. Bought the Swiss steak that was pre tenderized. ¬†Very easy recipe.
I never knew what to do with Swiss steak but after finding this recipe, I won‚Äôt look any further. Absolutely yummy!!
Excellent. Made in crockpot and a little liquidy so don‚Äôt add any more liquid when cooking
Delish!!
Looked and tasted just how my mom made it for me 40 years ago. Brought back good memories.

Very good recipe. I tenderized the raw meat on each side with onion power and pepper for a half an hour then added salt, flour. Also, like another poster I cut pieces into portions and went forward with the sauce. I upped the the O, SP, G, W by to 1.5 and double the T paste for a thicker, richer flavor. It turned out fabulous. So flavorful. Paired it with baby reds, and French green beans. This is a keeper. Thanks Alton. I love your take on recipes!

Since they no longer make the bag and bake seasoning blend I have been looking for a quality Swiss steak recipe and now I have found it. I simmered it covered in a pot on the stovetop for 2 and a half hours. After half an hour I tasted it and it seemed way too watery and too much sauce for the quantity of meat. Also the smoked paprika taste dominated. I had a feeling most of it would go in the bin. I allowed it to sit for an hour after cooking and the sauce thickened and flavors melded deliciously. I used 3 lbs. of steak and used one and a half times all the other ingredients and have enough for 2 nights supper.
Delish! Have tried other Swiss steak recipes and this wins hands down!! Meat was tender and could be cut with just a fork. I used fire roasted tomatoes for added flavor.
What a fantastic dinner! I wouldn‚Äôt change a thing! I will definitely make this again!
Great recipe. Takes quite some time to make but well worth it. I saute thin slices of green and red bell peppers and serve with mashed potatoes. Delicious
This is awesome. ¬†I put the leftover sauce on pasta for a second meal.

Haven‚Äôt had Swiss steak in years. This tastes exactly the way my mom used to make. Came out fork tender and the sauce is delicious. Followed the recipe exactly....except...sorry Alton but I had to add a dash of cayenne since we like a little kick.

OMG this was fabulous! I left out the celery because I don‚Äôt care for it cooked, but I don‚Äôt feel like I was missing it anyway, the juice/sauce was so flavorful and yummy as a gravy over mashed potatoes will definitely make this a go to recipe ‚ù§Ô∏è

OMG this was absolutely AMAZING. ¬†Only change I made is a little more beef broth, red and green pepper. ¬†My dad called and told me he ate three bowls. ¬†The sauce is so flavorful. ¬†Will make again.
Yummy.  Absolutely a do over.
Fantastic ‚Äî one of the best recipes I‚Äôve ever cooked from Alton Brown, or anyone else for that matter. So savory and delicious.
The smokiness of this recipe takes Swiss steak to another level! Only took 20 minutes in an instant pot.

I‚Äôve always purchased a Swiss steak ‚Äúkit‚Äù before with premade spices and a baking bag. That will never be repeated! This recipe is by far the best. I am so pleased with the taste and my husband agrees wholeheartedly!
We have a new favorite dinner. Thank you.
I made this because I had tomatoes and zucchini from the garden that I had to use.¬† I replaced the celery with zucchini.¬† The fresh garden produce just added another level of flavor.

Great recipe, classic Swiss steak.¬† But why bother to cut it into strips?¬† Do like my mother did.¬† Pound flour into each side with a meat mallet tenderizer, then do it again with more flour.¬† Brown the whole steak on each side, then proceed with the recipe.¬† After two hours the meat will be tender without the pain of trying to brown individual strips.

For over 40 years, I've used my mom's recipe for Swiss Steak. It's always been delicious, and it's one of those comfort food I crave a few times a year.

Just on a whim, I thought I would try Alton's recipe. I have to say, I'm blown away!

I hate when I read reviews where people say the recipe was awful, then you realize they made a ton of substitutions. Full disclosure: I did have to make a couple of substitutions,¬† but nothing huge:

* I used more flour to dredge the meat
* I used a 28 oz can of stewed tomatoes instead of a smaller can of diced
* I specifically used Mexican oregano
* I used a cup of chicken stock, not 1.5 cups of beef stock (less liquid here due to more from can)
* I tossed a dozen-ish small Yukon Golds in the pot, too
Something else different is that I've always used a mallet to whack the meat in the past, but today I used my needle smushy tool for the first time ever. It worked very well, and it was awesome cool.It took two hours to cook. Thankfully, I undersalted it for my taste. That way others can actually eat it. LOL!Anyway, this is very good. I like the depth of flavor. It's super yummy to me.

PS - The image for this recipe is unflattering and doesn't do it justice
Great ecupe
Superb. I added chopped carrots as well.

This is the second time I have made this dish and it turned out excellent both times.¬† The meat was fork tender and have off ample, thick gravy (I serve mashed potatoes with it.).¬† ¬†It has just the right amount of flavor and is juicy.¬† This recipe is a¬† hit with my family.¬† Next time I will serve Alton's buttermilk biscuits with it!

Pretty tasty! Being Southern I‚Äôve never used cubed steak for anything but chicken fried steak. My mother in law from Ohio is sheltered in with us and convinced me to try this recipe. (Chicken fried steak is too tough for her)
Glad I did. Did add a bay leaf and a tablespoon of brown sugar to tone down the acidity of the tomatoes.

I have probably made this Swiss Steak 50 times - no exaggeration - and it‚Äôs been wonderful every time. It‚Äôs a great dish to bring to a sick friend, a set of new parents, or to a potluck. ¬†I have yet to find someone who doesn‚Äôt love it.
This is an excellent recipe for Swiss Steak! The meat is very tender and the sauce is flavorful, rich with a lot of character. My husband really liked it too!  I will make this often!

We always did ours in my Mom's huge cast iron skillet.¬† Just 1 steak, beaten to death with a heavy coffee cup.¬† We did cook it on the stove for a couple of hours.¬† Never put it in the oven, always came out great!
I just finished eating it. I was really good, and my wife thought so too. Definitely a keeper.
This is awesome, thanks for another great recipe!
Super supper :)¬† Added a bell pepper and didn't change anything else.¬† Everyone enjoyed dinner.¬† Thanks Alton

very good put mine in slow
cooker was delish had with mash potatoes and corn.

Alton? What makes this Swiss?
So delicious by the way.

This recipe is absolutely AWESOME. ¬†I only had sun dried tomato paste so I used that instead of regular tomato paste. ¬†I think it just added to the depth of the flavor. ¬†I will definitely be making this again!!!!!
Great recipe! Just exactly what Swiss steak should taste like. My only addition was some sliced green bell pepper, to make it like my mother‚Äôs.
I made it with a London broil and followed the recipe as written. It came out delicious. I will make this again . I actually cooked it for an extra 1/2 hour.¬†
Check out the gourmet sections of Ross, tj Maxx, or Home Good stores. Great places to pick up those special spices! Loved this recipe I used pork loin steak last time. Friends loved that version also
Love this recipe :)¬† I use the crockpot and let it simmer all day.¬† My mother detests red meat, but she will eat this and requests it about twice a month.¬† Thank you!

This was delicious. The only thing to know, the long cooking time is important. I didn't cook mine long enough, just over an hour. The meat was tender, but not fork tender. I will cook the full recommended time.
My first time cooking with actual spices. Turned out awesome.

I NEVER thought I could find a swiss steak recipe that would beat my Dad's but Alton, you did it. ¬†Please forgive me Dad. ¬†My family and friends polish this dish off like you wouldn't believe. ¬†Thank you Mr. Brown! ¬†Cindy Thomas

My family loved this one. ¬†I was concerned because my husband doesn't usually like tomato based beef dishes other than spaghetti. ¬†He took seconds and told me to make sure to keep the recipe. ¬†A big hit with the family

My first time making Swiss Steak!¬† I had 2.5 pounds of beef, so it wouldn't submerge in my dutch oven.¬† I ended up adding a second can of diced tomatoes, and it was great!¬† ***I also used the baster to skim off some of the oil after I took it out of the oven.¬† My family enjoyed it!

My go to recipe every time! I've even made it in my pressure cooker to save time. So delicious, reminds me of Swiss steak my mom made when I was a child but even better. Lots of sauce for covering mashed potatoes as others have stated!¬†

I made Alton's swiss steak recipe last night and it was miles ahead of my old recipe.¬† Bonus... lots of sauce for sopping up with homemade bread or topping mashed potatoes!¬† My old recipe has been replaced!
This satisfies a craving I've had for weeks. The smoked paprika is excellent here. Loved it!

I've made this recipe several times and it is delicious and fork tender. So much better than my mother's old recipe. I had my husband to help me make it this weekend because I doubled it, using two roasts so we could share with family, and it was good to have help in trimming the fat and slicing the roast. I followed it exactly but tripled the sauce because the leftovers from this recipe make a wonderful base for vegetable-beef soup.¬†

I've never had an Alton Brown recipe to fail.

This is a great recipe that I've been making for years. ¬†I was, initially, looking for what my mother used to make, back in 1957, but that wasn't it. ¬†Of course, my mother was probably serving TV dinners, as she had a day job.
Terrible. Mushy and tasteless. Oily and a lot like overdone sloppy joes. I'll not be making this again.¬†
Holy cow- made this for supper. I'm seriously considering setting my alarm clock for the middle of the night to get up and eat more of it.
I made this last night and it was a hit! Definitely a keeper!¬†
So delicious.. made it just as written. A keeper

The ultimate recipe for Swiss Steak!
It's the best EVER. ¬†Thank you Alton Brown.

Unable to remember how to make swiss steak but looking for a recipe was very worth it. Reduced the smoked paprika a bit to 3/4 tsp and regular paprika 1/4 tsp, and oops I forgot the tomato paste. But it was great and everyone loved it so much very little leftovers for tomorrow. Will make this again but maybe a larger quantity for the leftovers. Great served with mashed potatoes. KEEPER RECIPE.

Ii did not use bacon and used tomato sauce rather than diced tomatoes. It was delicious on its own but I did have to add a bit of Picapepper sauce to spice it up for my family. Smoked paprika definitely plays a key role in the flavor.

Really delicious!¬† I always grew up with mushrooms in swiss steak gravy, so sliced and cooked those down with the onions and it was super :)¬† And agree 100% w/previous posters - SMOKED Paprika a must.¬† Plain is great for color, smoked is necessary for flavor.
Very good but be sure you use all of the beef broth or it will turn out dry. I really liked the seasoning.¬†
